results.title: How a Gay Republican Sees the Rise in Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Rhetoric on the Right
results.abstract: Amid an uptick in anti-gay rhetoric, Jane Coaston interviews Brad Polumbo, a gay Republican-leaning podcaster, about what’s happening on the right.

results.adx_keywords: Coronavirus (2019-nCoV);Long Covid;Chronic Condition (Health);Elderly;Therapy and Rehabilitation;Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns
results.title: Long Covid Poses Special Challenges for Seniors
results.abstract: Older people are less likely to be diagnosed but more likely to experience certain kinds of illnesses, research suggests.

media.caption: Patricia Anderson, who has endured 40 months of long Covid symptoms, on a folding seat cane that she now uses for stability. “I was very sick for a long time, and I never really got better,” she said.
media.copyright: Emily Elconin for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Space and Astronomy;Deaths (Obituaries);Apollo Project;Armstrong, Neil Alden;Aldrin, Buzz;Carpenter, Rene (1928-2020);Hanks, Tom;Lovell, James A Jr;Quinlan, Kathleen;Lovell, Marilyn;United States Naval Academy
results.title: Marilyn Lovell, Astronaut’s Wife in the Spotlight, Is Dead at 93
results.abstract: She embodied the glamour and the hardship of being married to an American hero. Her husband, Jim Lovell, was the captain of the ill-fated Apollo 13 mission in 1970.

media.caption: Marilyn Lovell in 1968 watching a training session for recovering a space capsule after a landing in the Gulf of Mexico. Her husband, Jim Lovell, was once the nation’s most experienced astronaut.

results.adx_keywords: Black People;Sailboats and Sailing;Records and Achievements;Deaths (Obituaries);Oceans and Seas;Pinkney, Bill;Mystic Seaport Museum;Cape Horn
results.title: Bill Pinkney, Globe-Circling Sailor Who Set a Racial Mark, Dies at 87
results.abstract: He was the first Black person to sail alone by way of the arduous southern route, rounding the perilous Cape Horn and withstanding storms and loneliness.

media.caption: Bill Pinkney in Chicago aboard his 47-foot cutter, Commitment, in September 1989. He set sail on his epic voyage the following August out of Boston.
media.copyright: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times

results.byline: By Camilo Ortiz and Lenore Skenazy
results.title: This Simple Fix Could Help Anxious Kids
results.abstract: Overprotection may be making kids scared of the world. If so, wouldn’t the obvious solution be more independence?

results.title: College Students: School Is Not Your Job
results.abstract: To get the maximum value out of those few golden years, treat them like leisure in the truest sense of the word.

results.adx_keywords: Police;Traffic and Parking Violations;Falsification of Data;Racial Profiling;Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings;Ken Barone;Connecticut Racial Profiling Prohibition Project;Connecticut
results.title: Over 100 Connecticut State Troopers Accused of Faking Traffic Stops
results.abstract: Auditors found tens of thousands of apparently falsified traffic stop records, many of white drivers. They suspect the officers were trying to appear more productive.

media.caption: James Rovella, right, commissioner of the Department of Emergency Services and Public Protection; Colonel Stavros Mellekas, center, superintendent of the Connecticut State Police; and Lt. Colonel Mark Davison testified at the State Capitol about the findings of a recent audit of state troopers’ traffic stops.

results.adx_keywords: Corruption (Institutional);Defense and Military Forces;Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Zelensky, Volodymyr;Ukraine
results.title: ‘Where Is the Money?’ Military Graft Becomes a Headache for Ukraine
results.abstract: The removal of the defense minister highlights the enduring challenge of corruption in Ukraine, which has emerged as a rare area of criticism of President Volodymyr Zelensky’s leadership.

media.caption: Ukrainian Army soldiers unload munitions from the back of a truck last week. Irregularities in procurement of weapons have been a persistent challenge for Ukraine.

results.title: Amid Rain and Mud, Climactic ‘Burn’ Is Delayed at Burning Man Fest
results.abstract: Officials urged campers to conserve food and water on Sunday, as the police investigated one death. The annual burning of a manlike figure was postponed.

media.caption: Neal Katyal walked six miles with a small group to the nearest town of Gerlach, Nev.

results.title: America Is Using Up Its Groundwater Like There’s No Tomorrow

results.title: What Is Labor Day? A History of the Workers’ Holiday.
results.abstract: President Grover Cleveland made it a national holiday in 1894, during a crisis over federal efforts to end a strike by railroad workers.

media.caption: A Labor Day parade on Main Street in Buffalo in 1900. President Grover Cleveland made Labor Day a national holiday in June 1894, as he faced a crisis of railway workers striking in Chicago.

results.title: Burning Man Attendees Begin to Leave Soggy Festival Site
results.abstract: After days of torrential rain, an exodus from the Nevada site began on Monday. The festival’s fiery climax, postponed twice, finally took place.

results.title: Big Farms and Flawless Fries Are Gulping Water in the Land of 10,000 Lakes
results.abstract: When Minnesota farmers cranked up their powerful wells, they blew through state limits. Thirsty crops included corn, soybeans and perfect, fry-friendly potatoes.

results.title: As Cases Soar, ‘Dementia Villages’ Look Like the Future of Home Care
results.abstract: A new generation of treatment facilities is aiming to integrate dementia patients with the communities around them, blurring lines between home and hospital.

media.caption: The Hogeweyk dementia village in Weesp, Netherlands, opened in 2009 as a new model for treating people with dementia. The facility resembles a quaint Dutch village, with a town square, restaurant and other amenities.

results.abstract: “The fact that I’m 56 and still realizing I never grieved when I was 11? That’s ridiculous,” says the CNN anchor.

results.byline: By Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
results.title: Kim Jong-un and Putin Plan to Meet in Russia to Discuss Weapons
results.abstract: Russia seeks more weaponry for its war in Ukraine, and a North Korean delegation recently traveled to Russia by train to plan for Mr. Kim’s visit this month, officials say.

media.caption: A photograph released by North Korean state news shows Kim Jong-un, right, with Sergei K. Shoigu, the Russian defense minister, in July. Mr. Kim is expected to travel to meet President Vladimir V. Putin in Russia.
